intro: Catostemma marahuacense, commonly known as the Mexican moonflower, is a flowering plant native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It belongs to the family Apocynaceae, which includes many species with milky sap and showy flowers. The plant is characterized by its large, white, night-blooming flowers that emit a sweet fragrance, attracting nocturnal pollinators like moths. It typically grows in tropical and subtropical regions, thriving in moist, well-drained soils. Due to its unique blooming habits and ornamental value, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens, though it can be invasive in certain areas.
